questions.text: A 22-Year-old female, G3A2, with 14 weeks of gestation, presented to OBG Opd for obstetric care as she is a case of cervical incompetence and was advised to undergo cerclage surgery. She had spontaneous painless abortions previously at 16 and 18 weeks of gestation. She was diagnosed with cervical incompetence before conception and was counseled for the same. She has no signs of miscarriage now. She has no comorbidities. Her previous USG and lab investigations are normal. There are no fetal anomalies present. McDonald's Cervical cerclage was done. The complications of this procedure could be all except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Post-term labor The given clinical scenario points towards cervical incompetence with cerclage repair treatment.

Highyeild:

Cervical incompetence is characterized by painlessness. cervical dilatation in the second or early third trimester with ballooning of the amniotic sac into the vagina, followed by rupture of membranes and expulsion of a usually live fetus. The usual time is 16 to 24 weeks. Note: With every loss, the gestational age at which abortion occurs keeps on decreasing in contrast to syphilis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The Complications could be – Slipping or cutting through the suture. ii. Option: A. Chorioamnionitis . iii. Option: B. Rupture of the membranes. iv. Abortion/preterm labor. v. Option: D. Cervical lacerations during surgery. vi. Cervical scarring and dystocia requiring cesarean delivery.

Extraedge:

Causes: The retentive power of the cervix (internal os) may be impaired functionally and anatomically due to the following conditions: (a) Congenital Uterine anomalies. (b) Acquired (iatrogenic) — common, following: (i) D and C operation, (ii) induced abortion by D and E (10%), (iii) vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix, and (iv) amputation of the cervix, or cone biopsy of trachelectomy. (c) Others- multiple gestations before preterm birth. Cervical incompetence is considered a biological continuum of spontaneous preterm birth syndrome (see p. 201).

questions.text: A 27-Year-old G3A2 with eight weeks of gestation presents to OBG Opd for her first ANC as she had UPT positive. She has no comorbidities. On questioning about her previous pregnancies, she says she had spontaneous abortions at 17 weeks and 18 weeks before. There was no history of trauma. On examination, P-90/min, BP-126/84mmHg, RR-12/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor present. Abdominal examination is normal. She was suspected to have cervical incompetence and was advised sonography to look for cervical length and funneling. The causes for cervical incompetence are all except?

options.label: B
options.text: Induced abortion by D and E

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above The given clinical scenario is that of a female with recurrent miscarriage suspected to have cervical incompetence. All the given options could be a cause for cervical incompetence. Hence none of the above is the correct answer. Causes of cervical incompetence : The retentive power of the cervix (internal os) may be impaired functionally and anatomically due to the following conditions: (a) Congenital Uterine anomalies. (b) Acquired (iatrogenic) —standard, following: (i) D and C operation

Highyeild:

Diagnosis: History: The typical narrative of painless rupture of membranes followed by the quick delivery of a live fetus in mid-trimester is very suggestive. Nonpregnant state: The internal os allows the passage of a No. 8 Hegar's cervical dilator or Foley catheter filled with 1 ml water without resistance. Premenstrual Hysterocervicography will show the t- The average cervical length at 14ypical funneling of the internal os Q (Fig. 9.1) In Pregnancy: Transvaginal ultrasound is the ideal method to follow up and detect early incompetence. The Normal Cervical Length at 14 weeks is 35-40 mm. A cervical length less than 25 mm, funneling of the os, and os diameter > 1 cm on USG indicate cervical incompetence. Note: Funneling is the ultrasound finding of herniation of the fetal membranes into the upper part of the endocervical canal. Figs. 9.1A and B: Hysterographic shadow obtained in the premenstrual phase. (A) Competent cervix (B) Incompetent cervix showing funneling. (FW Funnel width, FL = Funnel length, CL = Cervical length)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. (ii) induced abortion by D and E Option: B. (10%), (iii) vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix Option: C. and (iv) amputation of the cervix or cone biopsy of trachelectomy. Others —multiple gestations, prior preterm birth. Cervical incompetence is a biological continuum of spontaneous preterm birth syndrome (see p. 201).

Extraedge:

KEY POINTS Cervical incompetence is primarily a clinical diagnosis. It is manifested with recurrent painless cervical dilatation and spontaneous mid-trimester miscarriage. USG diagnosis (during pregnancy): Short cervix <25 mm long and funneling of the internal Os >1 cm. Cervical incompetence is the ultimate manifestation of cervical weakness. It may either be due to the primary anatomic defect of the cervix or due to trauma or may be due to the complex pathology of infection or inflammation of decidua/membranes leading to uterine contractions and cervical ripening. A combination of all the factors may be present in a few The pathological process of spontaneous mid-trimester loss and preterm birth may be continuous, known as spontaneous preterm birth syndrome. Cervical cerclage may be done based on the patient's history (history indicated) or repeated ultrasound observation (ultrasound shown) or on physical examination as an emergency (emergent cerclage). Cervical cerclage is done at around 14 weeks of pregnancy, and the stitch is generally removed after 36 completed weeks. There are few contraindications and complications of cervical cerclage operations.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old female G3A2 with 12 weeks of gestation presents to OBG Opd for ANC. She is a case of cervical incompetence detected before the present pregnancy. She has no comorbidities. Her previous lab investigations and USG are normal. She had two previous MID trimester painless abortions due to cervical incompetence. There are no fetal anomalies, and her vitals and general examination are normal. She was planning for cerclage surgery. The surgery is contraindicated if- 1. Intrauterine infection 2. Ruptured membranes 3. Severe uterine irritability 4. Cervical dilatation > 4cm Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above The clinical case scenario given points towards cervical incompetence planned for cerclage treatment. The Contraindications for cerclage surgery are – (i). Intrauterine infection. (STATEMENT 1) (ii). Ruptured membranes. ( STATEMENT2) (iii). Presence of vaginal bleeding. (iv). Severe uterine irritability. (STATEMENT 3) (v). Cervical dilatation greater than 4 cm. (STATEMENT 4) (vi). Fetal death or defect. Hence all of the above is the appropriate answer.

Highyeild:

Management The treatment is surgical by cervical credit, which can be doneprophylacial or in an emergency (Rescue cerclage) Time of operation: Prophylactic cervical circle is usually delayed up to 12-14 weeks so that miscarriage due to other causes can be eliminated. It should be done at least two weeks earlier than the lowest period of earlier wastage (but never earlier than ten weeks). Note: Sonography should be done before the circle to confirm a live fetus and to rule out anomalies. Removal of Cerclage Stitch: The Stitch should be removed at 37 weeks or earlier if labor pain starts or features of abortion appear.

Extraedge:

Procedures: Vaginal circlage Mc Donald's operation Shirodkar's operation • It has good success rate and less blood loss. • The most commonly performed Ocedure nowadays. • The Shirodkar operation is technically more involved and takes longer to Abdominal cerclage Indications Women with incomplete cervix due to severe trauma to the cervix, such as deep laceration, extensive conization, or repeated LEP to treat Ca in situ. H/O repetitive 2nd-trimester loss and failed vaginal circles. In women with 2nd-trimester losses and anatomic impossibility to place a vaginal cerclage.

questions.text: A 30-Year-oldG3A2 with 16 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen and bleeding pv. She is a case of cervical incompetence and was advised to follow up at 12 weeks of gestation. She has had two previous painless spontaneous abortions at 14 and 16 weeks of gestation. She has no comorbidities. On examination, vitals are normal. Pv examination shows bleed, cervical dilated - 3cm, and some products of conception present. USG shows a viable fetus with cardiac activity. The non-surgical alternatives to cervical cerclage surgery could be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above The given clinical scenario is that of cervical incompetence with threatened miscarriage.

Highyeild:

Etiology: Congenital Developmental weakness of cervix. Associated with uterine anomalies like the septate Following in-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Acquired due to previous cervical trauma Forcible dilatation during MTP and D and C. Conisation of cervix. Cauterisation of cervix. Amputation of the cervix or Fothergill's operation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Alternative to cervical cerclage—(nonsurgical) may be Option: A. bed rest alone to avoid pressure on the cervix. Option: B. Injection of 17alpha-hydroxyprogesterone caproate 500 mg IM weekly is given as cervical incompetence is considered a continuum of the preterm birth syndrome. Option: C. Use of vaginal pessary, when the cervix is found short on ultrasound, is found helpful. Hence all of the above is an appropriate answer.

Extraedge:

KEY POINTS Cervical incompetence is primarily a clinical diagnosis. It is manifested with recurrent painless cervical dilatation and spontaneous mid-trimester miscarriage. USG diagnosis (during pregnancy): Short cervix <25 mm long and funneling of the internal Os >1 cm. Cervical incompetence is the ultimate manifestation of cervical weakness. It may either be due to the primary anatomic defect of the cervix or due to trauma or may be due to the complex pathology of infection or inflammation of decidua/membranes leading to uterine contractions and cervical ripening. A combination of all the factors may be present in a few cases. The pathological process of spontaneous mid-trimester loss and preterm birth may be continuous, known as spontaneous preterm birth syndrome. Cervical cerclage may be done based on the patient's history (history indicated) or repeated ultrasound observation (ultrasound shown) or on physical examination ars an emergency (emergent cerclage). Cervical cerclage is done at around 14 weeks of pregnancy, and the stitch is generally removed after 36 completed weeks. There are few contraindications and complications of cervical cerclage operations.
